The distance of the moon to earth varies, so it isn't always the same size. Also, due to trig and atmospheric lensing, it will always span a marginally shorter arc near the horizon, while exposing more of its surface than when it is at the zenith of the sky. So technically, you are seeing more of the moon at the horizon where it appears largest and is actually measurably smallest (shortest arc span).

What?  No, no and no.  The phenomenon is not an illusion of context to related surroundings, but rather, the Moon is larger on the horizon because of water vapor.  There is more water vapor to look through on the horizon than there is looking up toward the heavens, therefore, the water vapor acts like a 'lensing affect' to make the moon appear larger on the horizon. Water molecules diminish drastically as you move up in altitude.  For example, at an altitude above 30,000 feet it, water moisture content is generally less than 6%, vs. looking across miles and miles of atmosphere on the horizon with over 50% plus water vapor.  So no, looking through your legs upside down with your bootie in the air may apply elsewhere, but does not adequately explain why the Moon appears as large as a silver dollar on Moon rise or Moon set. Good effort, but your references do not apply to the actual physics in play here.  Pretty funny though . . .ref: paying attention in Junior High Science class

"What if I told you that moon is the exact same size as every other time you've seen it in the sky"

Not entirely true.  Like all orbits, the moon's around the Earth isn't perfectly circular.  The moon's apparent diameter on the sky will vary by as much as 12.4% as the eccentricity of its orbit brings it nearer to and then farther from the Earth.  Doesn't explain the moon illusion, but if you see the moon and it looks particularly big, it may in fact be bigger than the last time you looked and paid attention.

The Moon Illusion is not that much of a mystery:
Do this: Take a photo of the moon at both the overhead and horizontal positions with your camera, and lay the photos side by side. You will see that they moon is equal size in each photo.
So the difference is in the normal camera you used, and the camera of your eyes
What you call the “moon illusion” is happening because of the effect of gravity on your liquid eye ball.
When you look upwards, the shape of the eye ball changes so that the lens of the eye comes closer to your retina, and your eye works like a wide angle lens, seeming to make the moon or sun (or any object up in the sky, such as a bird) move further away and appear smaller.
When you look horizontally with the surface of the earth, the shape of the eye ball changes so the lens moves further away from the retina, and your eye works like a telephoto lens, seeming to make the moon and all objects in your field of view seem larger.
Look at the moon upside down!  Funny shit!
Interestingly, the moon high up appears a tiny bit larger because the earth has turned one toward it. Small difference, but measurable.

That's a lunar eclipse.  The earth's shadow is being cast on the moon, but the moon is far enough away from the earth that some of the light from the sun still reaches it. Black holes give off a sound wave that resonates at a frequency of about 3x10^-7 Hz, which is about one cycle every 38.58 Earth days. We would never perceive such a low tone, since the lowest audible range to humans is around 20 Hz. But after a few hundred years (since sound would move very slowly through the incredibly low density medium of space) all the gas molecules around the black hole would rumble at that same low pitch.

Actually, there IS a sound in space. Space is not an actual vacuum, it has an average density of about 1 particle per cubic centimeter. The collisions, especially at such low temperatures, would be slow and nonenergetic, but there is a sound/compression wave that propogates. The only reason you wouldn't be able to "sense" the sound, is because the pressure is too high inside your ear drum, as compared to outside of it, to cause any noticeable vibrations.

It's because the hot surfaces cause the air to heat up. Hot gasses expand and become less dense, which causes the hot air to rise. Also the lower density allows light to travel faster, because there is less for it to interact with. When it hits the colder air, it slows down again, which causes it to bend. It's the same sort of thing when light passes through water. The bending of the light is why the air seems to distort around hot surfaces.

There IS a lens-like effect from the atmosphere. The atmosphere's refraction makes the Moon SMALLER in the vertical dimension when it is near the horizon. There is also a geometric factor due to distance: when the Moon is on the horizon, it is about 3950 miles (=the radius of the Earth) farther away than when it is high overhead. Both of these effects make the Moon slightly SMALLER on average when it is near the horizon. This is all objectively measurable.

In fact, the Moon is SMALLER near the horizon than when it's higher in the sky on any given night. It's smaller in the vertical dimension thanks to refraction, which "squishes" the Moon top to bottom. And it's also objectively smaller in both dimensions because it's further away when it's on the horizon than when it's high in the sky by about 1.6%. The smallest Moon you can ever see is one low on the horizon when the Moon is also at apogee.

Because our atmosphere scatters blue light the most. When the Sun is low in the sky, near the horison, the sunrays have to go through more of the atmosphere before it reaches you, and since the atmosphere scatters blue light, the blue sunrays isn't able to reach you, thereby making Sun less blue, or more red. When the sun is at it's highest the rays are taking the shortest possible path down to the ground and isn't scattered as much, therefore all the colors are preserved and the light is white.

This explanation is entirely incorrect.  It has nothing to do with points of reference.  It's all about how our brains model the sky, which is as a flattened dome.  The moon on the horizon is perceived as further away than the moon high in the sky.  Since they're both the same size on our retinas, we interpret the horizon moon as larger than the sky moon (look up the Ponzo Illusion).
